phrase: Karen is a 34-year-old female with a history of chronic migraines and hypertension who is here today with abdominal pain.
Abdominal pain started about ten days ago with mild discomfort on my side and it seems to be getting worse over the last couple of days.
The pain waxes and wanes in severity, generally around a four or five but sometimes up to seven or eight.
The pain is usually worse after a meal and localized to the side, with mild radiation to the left.
No nausea or vomiting, but some nausea and heartburn.
Pain is tender to touch and worsens in certain positions when severe.
No urinary symptoms, blood in urine, diarrhea, or blood in stool.
Appetite decreased due to nausea, and fatigue over the last week.
No unusual travel or exposures recently, except returning to Wisconsin.
Migraines are rare, managed with Excedrin Migraine, and sumatriptan for breakthrough pain.
Blood pressure at home is controlled (systolic 120s-130s, diastolic 70s), but slightly elevated in the office.
Grade 3 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur unchanged from prior exam.
Mild to moderate tenderness in the right upper quadrant with equivocal Murphyâ€™s sign.
Ordered CBC, chem 12, urinalysis, pregnancy test, and right upper quadrant ultrasound.
Concern for gallstones or cholecystitis based on tenderness.
Advised to remain NPO pending test results.
Continued lisinopril 20 mg daily with refill, and sumatriptan refill for migraines.
Counseling on avoiding alcohol/caffeine binges and maintaining sleep for migraines.
Follow-up in four weeks or sooner based on test results.
Patient denies fever but reports chills.
